Message.TypeName: Do not dispose objects multiple times
Message.Issue: Object 'fb' can be disposed more than once in method 'f1.checkUpdates()'. To avoid generating a System.ObjectDisposedException you should not call Dispose more than one time on an object.: Lines: 849

'f1.InvokeIfRequired(Control, MethodInvoker)' rethrows a caught exception and specifies it explicitly as an argument. Use 'throw' without an argument instead, in order to preserve the stack location where the exception was initially raised.
Because it is a P/Invoke method, 'WinApi.PostMessage(IntPtr, int, IntPtr, IntPtr)' should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.
Change the accessibility of P/Invoke 'WinApi.PostMessage(IntPtr, int, IntPtr, IntPtr)' so that it is no longer visible from outside its assembly.
Because it is a P/Invoke method, 'WinApi.RegisterWindowMessage(string)' should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.
Change the accessibility of P/Invoke 'WinApi.RegisterWindowMessage(string)' so that it is no longer visible from outside its assembly.

To reduce security risk, marshal parameter 'message' as Unicode, by setting DllImport.CharSet to CharSet.Unicode, or by explicitly marshaling the parameter as UnmanagedType.LPWStr. If you need to marshal this string as ANSI or system-dependent, specify MarshalAs explicitly, and set BestFitMapping=false; for added security, also set ThrowOnUnmappableChar=true.
Because it is a P/Invoke method, 'WinApi.SetForegroundWindow(IntPtr)' should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.
Change the accessibility of P/Invoke 'WinApi.SetForegroundWindow(IntPtr)' so that it is no longer visible from outside its assembly.
Because it is a P/Invoke method, 'WinApi.ShowWindow(IntPtr, int)' should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.
Change the accessibility of P/Invoke 'WinApi.ShowWindow(IntPtr, int)' so that it is no longer visible from outside its assembly.

Rule.TypeName: Do not dispose objects multiple times
Rule.Name: Do not dispose objects multiple times
Rule.Description: A correctly implemented Dispose method can be called multiple times without throwing an exception. However, this is not guaranteed and to avoid generating a System.ObjectDisposedException you should not call Dispose more than one time on an object.
Rule.Resolution: Object {0} can be disposed more than once in method {1}. To avoid generating a System.ObjectDisposedException you should not call Dispose more than one time on an object.: Lines: 849

Rule.Name: Move P/Invokes to NativeMethods class
Rule.Description: This type contains members with the DllImport attribute. Members with the DllImport attribute should be contained in classes named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.
Rule.Resolution: Because it is a P/Invoke method, {0} should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.

Rule.Name: P/Invokes should not be visible
Rule.Description: Interop layer should not be public. The DllImport attribute should not be applied to publicly accessible members (public or protected).
Rule.Resolution: Change the accessibility of P/Invoke {0} so that it is no longer visible from outside its assembly.

Rule.Name: Rethrow to preserve stack details
Rule.Description: Use the IL rethrow instruction to preserve original stack details when re-raising a caught exception.
Rule.Resolution: {0} rethrows a caught exception and specifies it explicitly as an argument. Use 'throw' without an argument instead, in order to preserve the stack location where the exception was initially raised.

Rule.Name: Specify marshaling for P/Invoke string arguments
Rule.Description: When marshaling strings as ANSI (or as Auto on Win9x), some characters may be changed. If best-fit mapping is on, strings that appear different in Unicode will be marshaled to identical ANSI strings, which may lead to incorrect security decisions. Turning best-fit mapping off reduces this risk, as all characters without equivalents are mapped to '?'. Also, note that CharSet.Ansi is the default setting for all string marshaling; Unicode marshaling must be specified explicitly, either as a CharSet setting of DllImport or StructLayout, or as a MarshalAs attribute with a Unicode (or system-dependent) UnmanagedType.
Rule.Resolution: To reduce security risk, marshal parameter {0} as Unicode, by setting DllImport.CharSet to CharSet.Unicode, or by explicitly marshaling the parameter as UnmanagedType.LPWStr. If you need to marshal this string as ANSI or system-dependent, specify MarshalAs explicitly, and set BestFitMapping=false; for added security, also set ThrowOnUnmappableChar=true.
